results.title: The Best of the Addams Family. -Volume 4
results.brief_description: The creepy and kooky Addams family; Gomez, Morticia, Uncle Fester, Grandmama, Thing, Lurch, Pugsley and Wednesday are here for two episodes from the original television series. In “New neighbors meet the Addams family”, newlyweds Hubert and Amanda Peterson’s (Peter Brooks and Cynthia Pepper) honeymoon begins on a sour note when they move into the house next door to the Addams family. Alarmed by Fester tunneling into their house, Grandmama grinding the axe and Morticia and Gomez bathing the octopus, they must grin and bear it in an attempt to move out of the house. Directed by Jean Yarbrough. In “Morticia, the matchmaker”, Melancholia (Hazel Shermet), Morticia’s cousin, comes to visit after yet another future husband flees to join the Foreign Legion. After Gomez exhausts the list of eligible batchelors; a marriage broker, Lurch plus other business contacts, Melancholia sets her heart on a woman shy lawyer, Clarence P. Harvey (Lee Goodman) who has relutantly come to visit Gomez on business. Directed by Jerry Hopper. The series features

results.title: The Rumble in the jungle
results.creator_credit: Paul Doyle, Time-Warner and Turner Home Entertainment
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Muhammad Ali: the whole story”.
An in depth, six-part chronological document on one of the twentieth century’s greatest sportspersons, Muhammad Ali. At 33 years of age, Ali is at a crossroads. From being unbeatable to losing two straight bouts - first with Joe Frazier, who took the title, and then with Ken Norton who left Muhammad Ali badly beaten and with a broken jaw. His struggle to regain the title from Joe Frazier becomes an obsession but his critics grow ever more doubtful. On top of that, Ali receives the news that a new player is in town: Joe Frazier is brutally beaten by newcomer, George Foreman, the hardest hitting boxer of all time. Promoter Don King persuades Ali to fight Forman in Zaire for 5 million dollars. Includes interviews with friends, foes and those that worked closely with him. Muhammad Ali himself, was a consultant for this series. Written by Gary Cohen. Narrated by Don Maseng.

results.title: Fine and dandy; Things that go bump in the night
results.creator_credit: Maurice Sellar, Robert Sidaway and Rank Film Distributors
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Best of British”.
Fine and dandy illustrates the fame of British costume dramas in all their lavishness. A wonderfully romantic outcome was the main feature of these films which focused on the purity of love, whether the character was a lusty lord or a defenceless maiden. From malevolent spirits to demonic murderers, benevolent ghosts to spooky fortune tellers, British horror films will have you screaming and laughing in turn. Narrated by Sir John Mills.

results.title: All at sea; Film fun
results.creator_credit: Maurice Sellar, Robert Sidaway and Rank Film Distributors
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “The Best of British”.
All at sea focuses on the fine English tradition for “messing about in boats.” This episode explores action on the high sea from intrepid explorers like Columbus to heroes in submarines, as well as those heroic sea sagas and comic “fun on the ocean waves” films. “Film fun” highlights the visual comedy from Britain’s rich source of comedians such as Norman Wisdom, Frankie Howard, Peter Sellers and the Carry On crew who demonstrate the art of immaculate timing and pure visual technique. Narrated by Sir John Mills.

results.title: Classic tales; English Gentlemen
results.creator_credit: Maurice Sellar, Robert Sidaway and Rank Film Distributors
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “The Best of British”.
The ultimate collection of scenes from feature films inspired by the literary giants Shakespeare, Shaw, Dickens, Wilde and Wells. Some of the great classic films based on literature are featured including “Oliver Twist”, “Caesar and Cleopatra” and ‘The Importance of being Earnest’. In the episode entitled the “English gentlemen”, the image of this stereotype as portrayed in film is discussed. It is a reflection on the urbane and sometimes eccentric characters portrayed by such stars as Rex Harrison, Michael Wilding and Stanley Holloway. Narrated by Sir John Mills.

results.title: Heaven and earth; Love story
results.creator_credit: Maurice Sellar, Robert Sidaway and Rank Film Distributors
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “The Best of British”.
Heaven and Earth looks at how religion has provided British films with stories that have been dramatic, controversial and inspirational including classics like “Black narcissus” and “Conspiracy of hearts.” “Love story” looks at why there will always be an audience for great film love stories such as “Romeo and Juliet”, “Brief encounter”, and “Seventh veil.” Narrated by by Sir John Mills.

results.title: The Road back
results.creator_credit: Paul Doyle, Time-Warner and Turner Home Entertainment
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Muhammad Ali: the whole story”.
An in depth, six-part chronological document on one of the twentieth century’s greatest sportspersons, Muhammad Ali. This episode begins in 1970. Ali is the most loved and the most despised athlete in the world. He is in his prime, the fasted heavyweight boxer in the world. He is at a time when all other great and powerful boxers don’t even come close. He has never lost a fight. All but two of his long list of bouts were by knockout - until he fights Joe Frazier. Includes interviews with friends, foes and those that worked closely with him. Muhammad Ali himself, was a consultant for this series. Written by Gary Cohen. Narrated by Don Maseng.

results.title: Exile
results.creator_credit: Paul Doyle, Time-Warner and Turner Home Entertainment
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Muhammad Ali: the whole story”.
An in depth, six-part chronological document on one of the twentieth century’s greatest sportspersons, Muhammad Ali. This episode starts in March, 1967, and critics are starting to call Ali one of the greatest boxers of all time. As his fame grows, so does his extraordinary glib manner culminating in his famous quote: “I aint got no quarrel with the Viet Cong.” Ali becomes a conscientious objector and from avoiding the draft because of his religious beliefs, he is stripped of his title and coined an outlaw in the Spring of ‘67. Includes interviews with friends, foes and those that worked closely with him. Muhammad Ali himself, was a consultant for this series. Written by Gary Cohen. Narrated by Don Maseng.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paul Doyle, Time-Warner and Turner Home Entertainment

Episode number 3 of Series “Muhammad Ali: the whole story”.
An in depth, six-part chronological document on one of the twentieth century’s greatest sportspersons, Muhammad Ali. This episode starts in March, 1967, and critics are starting to call Ali one of the greatest boxers of all time. As his fame grows, so does his extraordinary glib manner culminating in his famous quote: “I aint got no quarrel with the Viet Cong.” Ali becomes a conscientious objector and from avoiding the draft because of his religious beliefs, he is stripped of his title and coined an outlaw in the Spring of ‘67. Includes interviews with friends, foes and those that worked closely with him. Muhammad Ali himself, was a consultant for this series. Written by Gary Cohen. Narrated by Don Maseng.
description_for_label:
Episode number 3 of Series “Muhammad Ali: the whole story”.
An in depth, six-part chronological document on one of the twentieth century’s greatest sportspersons, Muhammad Ali. This episode starts in March, 1967, and critics are starting to call Ali one of the greatest boxers of all time. As his fame grows, so does his extraordinary glib manner culminating in his famous quote: “I aint got no quarrel with the Viet Cong.” Ali becomes a conscientious objector and from avoiding the draft because of his religious beliefs, he is stripped of his title and coined an outlaw in the Spring of ‘67. Includes interviews with friends, foes and those that worked closely with him. Muhammad Ali himself, was a consultant for this series. Written by Gary Cohen. Narrated by Don Maseng.
